item.description:
** No charge for this event! **

If you’re a baseball fan, you know a lot about the game: the
teams, the players, the rules, the traditions, and the words
to “Take Me Out to the Ballgame.” But do you know enough about
the science of baseball answer these questions?

1) How does a curveball curve?
2) Does a fastball "rise?"
3) How does a knuckleball work?
4) What do baseball scouts actually do when watching games?
5) What is sabermetrics?
6) What matters to more Theo Epstein: scouting or sabermetrics?
7) How much does muscle strength matter in baseball?
8) Do steroids help baseball players?
9) What is pitch f/x? Hit f/x?
10) Should players who used steroids be admitted to the Hall of
Fame?

If you want to raise your own game this season, Andy Andres and
the MIT Science of Baseball program would like to pitch you
some science before you take the field—or your seat. If you
think that the answer to that last question has nothing to do
with science, what you learn might change your mind.

Friday, April 30
6-7:30 PM
MIT Campus, Stata Center
32 Vassar Street, Room 32-155

**We can scoot around the corner after this event to watch the Sox @ Baltimore**
--------------------------

Dr. Andy Andres, a diehard Red Sox fan, earned his PhD in Human
Nutritional Sciences and Physiology from Tufts University. He
is a member of the Faculty at Boston University's College of
General Studies in Natural Sciences and Mathematics where he
teaches biology and physics. At Tufts University, he teaches
one of the first college-level courses ever offered in
Sabermetrics. For 17 years, he taught a seminar in exercise
physiology and ergogenic aids for athletic performance at
Harvard College. In the summer, Andy teaches science and
coaches baseball in the MIT Science of Baseball Program.

As a Datacaster/Stringer for Major League Baseball Advanced
Media, Andy is responsible for scorekeeping games at Fenway
Park for various Internet applications, including mlb.com's
Gameday and Bloomberg Sports. For Ron Shandler’s BaseballHQ.
com, he analyzes baseball statistics and writes baseball
research analyses.
item.name: The Science of Baseball talk by MLB Datacaster
